attributes.name: Wiener Stadt- und Landesarchiv - Magistratsabteilung 8
parallelFormsOfName: Municipal and Provincial Archives of Vienna - Municipal Department 8
attributes.history: The Wiener Stadt- und Landesarchiv collect, store, and preserve documents and records regarding the history of Vienna. Municipal and Provincial Archives additionally act as the city's history and local government documentation and research center.
attributes.holdings: Collections of the Wiener Stadt- und Landesarchive include but are not limited to: city office records, records of executive offices and authorities, former townships [Stadtarchiv]; state administrative records, state court records, police records, political party records, and records of private institutions [Landesarchiv]. Among others contains restitution- and/or compensation-related materials: 1. Magistratsabteilung 119 / Vermögensentzug-Anmeldungsverordnung; 2. Opferfürsorgeakten; closed files; restriction: extended period for protection of personal data
attributes.openingTimes: Use of the Archives reading room is available by appointment. Use of the Archives' computers in the reading room is also possible.

attributes.name: Österreichischer Fonds für Versöhnung, Frieden und Zusammenarbeit
parallelFormsOfName: Fund for Reconciliation, Peace and Cooperation
attributes.history: The Austrian Reconciliation Fund has accomplished its task and was closed by 31 December 2005. It is therefore not possible anymore to forward applications to this fund or to obtain payments from it. In total, 132.395 persons from 70 countries have submitted their files to the Reconciliation Fund and obtained a payment from it. In 2005/6 all restution files were handed over to Austria's State Archive; access seems restricted.
attributes.holdings: Among others contains restitution- and/or compensation-related materials.

attributes.name: Österreichisches Staatsarchiv–Archiv der Republik
parallelFormsOfName: Austrian State Archives - Archives of the Republic
attributes.history: Over the years, dating back to the time of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, efforts have been made to centralize archival institutions of Austria. Between 1940 and 1945 significant work was done to centralize these state archives, while Austria was part of Germany's Third Reich. In 1983 the "Archiv der Republik" was founded as part of the Austrian archival system. Consequently other departments of the State Archives had to transfer to it their official records of the First Republic, the National-Socialist era and the Second Republic. In 1981 a new building was created in Vienna-Erdberg (Nottendorfer Gasse 2-4, 1030 Vienna); today it holds the General Directorate, the restoration workshop, the central library of the State Archives and the following archival departments: Allgemeines Verwaltungsarchiv, Archiv der Republik, Kriegsarchiv and Finanz- und Hofkammerarchiv.
attributes.holdings: The Archiv der Republik, the archive of contemporary Austrian history, is responsible for the records of the central services of the Austrian federal administration (President’s Chancellery, Federal Chancellery, federal ministries, central agencies and subordinate offices of the ministries and the Federal Chancellery), since the creation of the Republic of Austria in 1918. The holdings, which total 66,000 linear metres, are organized into 22 record groups, subsequently organized by contents. Though not technically belonging to the Republic of Austria, records from the Nazi period are found in the Archiv der Republik.

attributes.name: Nationalfonds und Allgemeiner Entschädigungsfonds
parallelFormsOfName: National Fund and General Settlement Fund

address.streetAddress: Parliament A-1017, Kirchberggasse 33 (post address: Parlament, Dr. Karl Renner Ring 3, A1017 Wien)

attributes.history:
The “National Fund of the Republic of Austria for Victims of National Socialism“ was founded by the National Council in 1995 to make payments to victims of National Socialism in recognition of Austria’s special moral responsibility towards them. The object of the Fund, which was established by Federal Law, is to make payments to victims of National Socialism in recognition of Austria’s special moral responsibility towards them. Since its establishment approximately 30000 claimants have received what has been referred to as symbolic payments in recognition of the injustice they suffered as victims of National Socialism. 

In the course of time further tasks were entrusted to the National Fund, partly on the basis of the Washington Agreement of 2001, to compensate property losses–rental income, household furnishings and personal valuables. Apart from symbolic and compensatory payments the Fund also deals, under the “Looted Art Restitution Act“, with looted works of art for which no claim of inheritance has been established and devotes itself, through project promotion and PR activities, to awareness-building regarding the NS era and its consequences. The General Settlement Fund for Victims of National Socialism: Established in 2001 to solve unresolved settlement issues. In 2001 another Federal Law was passed on the basis of the Washington Agreement, creating the General Settlement Fund for Victims of National Socialism. Its object was to develop general solutions to resolve as yet unresolved settlement issues. It allowed compensation claims for loss of business assets, real estate (unless restituted in kind–in rem restitution), capital assets, movable property (unless covered by rental loss compensation through the National Fund), occupational and educational losses and other losses or damage incurred. In rem restitution of real estate. The Washington Agreement provided for in rem restitution (i.e. the actual return of the property into the hands of its original owners or their heirs) of real estate looted by the NS regime and currently held as public property. In addition, the law envisages the restitution of movable property to Jewish communities. Provisions relating to in rem restitution form the second focal point, apart from compensation payments of the Settlement Fund Law. 

Implementing Organs:
The Board of Trustees and the Secretary General are the joint organs of the National Fund and the General Settlement Fund. Applications to the National Fund are decided by its Committee, while applications to the General Settlement Fund are handled by the independent Claims Committee, and applications for in rem restitution by an independent arbitration panel. The Board of Trustees is composed of the three Presidents of the National Council, representatives of the Federal Government and further members elected by the National Council Main Committee, including representatives of victims’associations and religious communities. The Board is chaired by the President of the National Council.
attributes.holdings: Among others contains restitution- and/or compensation-related materials.

address.streetAddress: Büro im Dokumentationsarchiv desösterreichischen Widerstandes: c/o DÖW, Wipplingerstrasse 6-8, Stiege 3

attributes.history: On 14 December 1998 in the presence of the federal minister of justice, Dr. Nikolaus Michalek founded FStN, which holds records of Nazi crimes within Austria.
attributes.holdings: The Research Center for post-war Trials a holding area for altogether knowledge of the records, thus not only the files but additionally paper copies, microfilm and digital media. The center provides both electronic finding aids and microfilm copies. Research and development work occurs at the Dokumentationsarchiv des österreichischen Widerstandes (DÖW), and microfilms are kept in the Österreichischen Staatsarchiv.

attributes.name: Oberösterreichisches Landesarchiv
attributes.history: The Oberösterreichische Landesarchiv, founded 10 January 1986, is a cultural institute and a central archive for state and district authorities of Upper Austria. Of central significance today within the archive is the collection and analysis of Austrian historical source material and to subsequently establish its wider accessibility.
attributes.holdings: Over 900 collections are held within the Oö. Landesarchiv, separated in several individual archival groups, including: the territorial estate archive (Archiv der Landstände), state administration archive, court and financial authority archive, as well as extensive secular and religious manorial records. Court records of crimes of the Nazi regime appear to be present within the Gerichtsarchive. Military records from the Nazi period are also present and can be found in the "Militärische Sammlungen" under the category "Weitere Bestände." Among others contains restitution- and/or compensation-related materials: 1. Opferfürsorge-Akten Oberösterreich (deceased applicants); 2. Finanzabteilung Bestand Rückstellungen; 3. LG Linz, Sondergerichte–Rückstellungskommission; closed files; restriction: retention period 100 years, access permitted for scientific projects

attributes.name: Niederösterreichisches Landesarchiv, Außendepot Bad Pirawarth
parallelFormsOfName: Lower Austrian State Archives, external depot Bad Pirawarth
attributes.history: The Lower Austrian State Archives hold former and present administrative and court records (documents, manuscripts and documents from the Middle Ages to the present day), and further archives of former landlords, court archives, documents of important figures, various collections, etc. On 18 November 1997 the new national archive in St. Pölten was created. The two departments and the NÖInstitut für Landeskunde were for the first time in the same location. The branch in Bad Pirawarth also remains.
attributes.holdings: The holdings of the district headquarters located in Bad Pirawarth have been moved to the newly constructed external depot, NÖLandesarchiv, in St. Pölten-West.
